channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Shireen Abu Akleh, a veteran reporter for the Al Jazeera news network, was shot and killed during an Israeli military raid into the West Bank city of Jenin https://t.co/ksE22EvGtv
Elon Musk says he would reverse Twitter’s ban on Donald Trump https://t.co/8j92dKeY7n
An organized crime prosecutor from Paraguay who was on his honeymoon in Colombia was assassinated Tuesday by gunmen who arrived at the private beach on jet skis https://t.co/sCfskLboU0
The Senate has voted to confirm Lisa Cook to the Federal Reserve, making her the first Black woman to sit on the central bank’s board https://t.co/yfRzSbF7pQ

Volkswagen is set to resurrect the Scout off-road vehicle brand as part of its bid to expand in the U.S., the world’s most profitable automotive market, as war and Covid-19 cloud its prospects in Europe, China https://t.co/tLeDNwBtdm
Russia will likely be targeted by yet more U.S. sanctions and export controls in response to its invasion of Ukraine, a senior U.S. official said https://t.co/VcpXtOxUSg
Apple’s iPod helped revolutionize the music industry when it was introduced more than two decades ago. Now, music fans will soon bid adieu to the portable player. https://t.co/UAojD2WjGt
From @WSJopinion: NATO should admit Finland and Sweden ASAP, writes @JohnRDeni. It would enhance the alliance’s security and send a powerful message to Russia. https://t.co/VmdVYV8c8O

Spain’s Carlos Alcaraz has yet to win a major tennis tournament. But after the 19-year-old phenom buzzed through Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Alexander Zverev to win the Madrid Open, the tennis world is stirred, writes sports columnist @jasongay. https://t.co/YilO39Jslw?
Breaking: Elon Musk said he would reverse Twitter’s ban on Donald Trump https://t.co/t0xSYveHcg
Digital banking platform Greenwood, created for Black and Latino customers, is acquiring a private professional membership club called The Gathering Spot https://t.co/q7QyWIWbqz
Miami locals complain that relocating New Yorkers are driving up apartment rents https://t.co/MNXQrteYaU
Attorney General Letitia James and state lawmakers say New York should pay for abortion access for low-income residents and out-of-state women https://t.co/5VNTY98eQy

South Korea’s new president said he would keep the door open for dialogue with North Korea and provide support for its fragile economy if Pyongyang stops developing nuclear weapons https://t.co/vRZWSZdeBr

Sri Lankan Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa has resigned after months of mass protests against his government’s handling of an economic crisis that has led to double-digit inflation, rolling blackouts and acute shortages in fuel and medicines https://t.co/wb3iX58TJi
An upstart financial firm backed by Peter Thiel and Bill Ackman has a message for American corporations: Focus on making money, not taking stands. https://t.co/8vZNiwsIKA
Residents of recently Russian-occupied villages surrounding Kyiv are returning, removing debris from their rubble-strewn homes, planting vegetables and planning for the future https://t.co/iSXShej2H8

Elon Musk has cultivated close ties with Beijing to build Tesla’s business in China. Now that he is buying Twitter, WSJ looks at how China has used the social-media platform to promote its views, and why that’s raising concerns https://t.co/UmqtY7rJDz
Elon Musk said his plans for Twitter are aligned with new European Union rules aimed at compelling social media companies to do more to police illegal content https://t.co/L8Di0X5gug
An Andy Warhol portrait of Marilyn Monroe has sold for $195 million at Christie's, setting a record for an American artwork at auction https://t.co/0YUxoawBWz
Protesters in Poland drenched Moscow’s ambassador to Warsaw in red paint Monday after swarming a local cemetery for Soviet soldiers who died in World War II https://t.co/QAsjtdRfN8

The Senate has passed a bill expanding police protections for Supreme Court justices to include their immediate family members, in the wake of protests following a leaked draft ruling indicating the court could overturn Roe v. Wade https://t.co/VHHCsX38CQ

The risk of electricity shortages is rising throughout the U.S. And electric-grid operators are warning of rolling blackouts during heat waves or other peak periods as soon as this year. https://t.co/7v6zUiYlt1
Ukrainians with ties to Russia like 98-year-old Olha Tverdokhlibova didn’t embrace the invasion, despite what President Vladimir Putin might have expected https://t.co/w4JHh8t2ZT
TikTok brain is real, researchers say, and it’s affecting kids’ cognitive development. "We’ve made kids live in a candy store." https://t.co/EM9sTccQRe

From @WSJopinion: The end of Roe v. Wade will be good for America, writes @Peggynoonannyc. The mistaken abortion decision, a product of vanity, roiled and distorted our politics and poisoned our culture. https://t.co/cmPjLnZl1U

U2's Bono and the Edge turned up in Ukraine to show support for its fight against Russia, performing in a Kyiv subway station. Singer Taras Topolia joined Bono in singing “Stand by Me”—changing the words to “Stand by Ukraine.” https://t.co/caAqTEcVU9

Protesters in Poland drenched Moscow’s ambassador to Warsaw in red paint after swarming a local cemetery for Soviet soldiers who died in World War II, disrupting his embassy's attempts to commemorate the end of the conflict https://t.co/WctDLMvCLT

Elon Musk has cultivated close ties with Beijing to build Tesla’s business in China. Now that he is buying Twitter, WSJ looks at how China has used the social-media platform to promote its views, and why that’s raising concerns https://t.co/vGWJ3A9DE1

French sportswear firm Salomon decided to start making sneakers in its home country. Building the supply chain hasn’t been easy in a country where shoemaking died out long ago. https://t.co/dP1iHJgMdt
Two Palestinians suspected of killing three Israelis in a bloody ax attack on Israel’s independence day were captured https://t.co/BrCMwjQTQu
Japan said it would phase out and eventually ban the import of Russian oil, reversing its earlier stance after a meeting of Group of Seven leaders https://t.co/uIteBszfZF

Marvel's “Dr. Strange in the Multiverse of Madness" raked in $450 million at the global box office its opening weekend, signaling a promising rebound ahead after two years of disrupted summer movie seasons https://t.co/CuVdeErtrz
Ukrainian forces making a last-ditch stand in the destroyed city of Mariupol have vowed to fight till the end: "We are basically dead men." https://t.co/wt3Wbmqxwy
Jared Kushner’s new private-equity fund plans to invest millions of dollars of Saudi Arabia’s money in Israeli startups, in a sign of warming ties between two historic rivals https://t.co/TwsPyByFvH

“Kids are a guarantee that you can get in here, it’s as if they were visas." It’s easier for migrants to be let into the U.S. if they're with their children. So some have started arriving at the border with bogus families. https://t.co/CJXg48YLWf

As semiconductor makers look to boost output amid soaring demand, they face a new concern: not enough chips to make more chips, @ahirtens explains #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/uI12ZDYuHA https://t.co/mlI8BQgwow

Wage increases are registering at a historically high rate but aren’t keeping up with inflation. The result is many workers are receiving big raises—and may still be struggling to pay for more expensive gasoline, groceries and rent. https://t.co/Tm6JVtbyim
First lady Jill Biden made an unannounced visit to Ukraine Sunday, meeting with the nation’s first lady, Olena Zelenska, near the country’s border with Slovakia https://t.co/8761bXuMhe
Ukrainian forces making a last-ditch stand in the destroyed city of Mariupol have vowed to fight till the end: "We are basically dead men." https://t.co/VPImHFkcTs
Along Russia’s longest supply line, Ukrainian villagers risked their lives to help Ukraine’s military target Kremlin forces https://t.co/PuIxiJw1Cc
From @WSJopinion: China should be worried that the war in Ukraine has Germany rethinking its conciliatory foreign policy, writes @josephsternberg https://t.co/CV0bbyeLlq

The risk of electricity shortages is rising throughout the U.S. And electric-grid operators are warning of rolling blackouts during heat waves or other peak periods as soon as this year. https://t.co/IEhPJCVmce
A Russian airstrike is believed to have killed some 60 villagers who had taken refuge in a school in the eastern Ukrainian region of Luhansk, authorities there said https://t.co/YeqIHRoOh3

Moscow is allowing importers to bring in Apple smartwatches, Lamborghinis, Sony PlayStations and dozens of other imported goods against the will of the companies that make them. https://t.co/oNzziNsNUt

Russian forces have taken grain from Ukrainian farms as part of an effort to hobble the country’s globally important agriculture sector, the Ukrainian government and farmers in the country said. https://t.co/tAhdqidukz
Facebook blocked hospitals and charities in Australia last year. The company said it was an accident. Whistleblowers say it was a negotiating tactic. https://t.co/NnM1L6olI0
Jared Kushner’s fund plans to invest millions of Saudi Arabia’s money in Israeli startups, people familiar say, in a sign of warming ties between the rivals https://t.co/lzexxUnB1C
Elon Musk broke nearly every rule in the deal-making playbook. How he landed Twitter anyway. https://t.co/fKddtC8yLS

From @WSJopinion: If some version of Justice Alito’s opinion is adopted, the Justices who sign onto it will have done what they promised Congress: Decide cases on the legal and constitutional merits. https://t.co/s801yCkkpX
